chapter.para: This chapter gives an overview on how to run through a default installation of &productname; for the &amd64;/&intel64; architecture.

sect1.title: Installing &productname;
sect1.para: Use the following procedures to set up a new &productnamereg; &productnumber; cluster.

sect2.title: System Requirements
sect2.para: Before you begin the installation, please make sure your system meets all requirements listed below.

listitem.para: Any AMD64/Intel* EM64T processor (quad-core processors are recommended). 32-bit processors are not supported.
8 GB physical RAM per node.
40 GB available disk space (or more depending on the count and size of container images you intend to run).
In order to communicate without interruptions, all nodes should to be on the same network.
A DHCP server to dynamically provide IP addresses and host names for the nodes in your cluster (unless you configure all nodes statically).
A DNS server to resolve host names. Please make sure you have reliable DNS resolution at all times, especially in combination with DHCP.

important.title: Unique Host Names
important.para: Host names must be unique. It is recommended to let the DHCP server provide not only IP addresses but also host names of the cluster nodes.

listitem.para: &productname; &productnumber; does not support remote installations with Virtual Network Computing (VNC).

sect1.para: The interactive installation of &productname; split into several steps is listed below.

To view the boot messages and copyright notices during this process, press . On completion of this process, the &yast; installation program starts and displays the graphical installer.

tip.title: Installation Without a Mouse
tip.para: If the installer does not detect your mouse correctly, use for navigation, arrow keys to scroll, and to confirm a selection. Various buttons or selection fields contain a letter with an underscore. Use Letter to select a button or a selection directly instead of navigating there with .

sect1.para: Configure the following mandatory settings on the Installation Overview screen.

tip.title: Help and Release Notes
tip.para: From this point on, a brief help document and the Release Notes can be viewed from any screen during the installation process by selecting Help or Release Notes respectively.

sect2.title: Keyboard Layout
sect2.para: The Keyboard Layout is initialized with the language settings you have chosen on the boot screen. Change it, if necessary.

sect2.title: Password for the &rootuser; User
sect2.para: &rootuser; is the name of the superuser, or the administrator of the system. Unlike regular users (who may or may not have permission to access certain areas or execute certain commands on the system), &rootuser; has unlimited access to change the system configuration, install programs, and set up new hardware. If users forget their passwords or have other problems with the system, &rootuser; can help. The &rootuser; account should only be used for system administration, maintenance, and repair. Logging in as &rootuser; for daily work is rather risky: a single mistake could lead to irretrievable loss of system files.
For verification purposes, the password for &rootuser; must be entered twice. Do not forget the &rootuser; password. After having been entered, this password cannot be retrieved.

tip.title: Passwords and Keyboard Layout
tip.para: It is recommended to only use characters that are available on an English keyboard. In case of a system error or when you need to start your system in rescue mode a localized keyboard might not be available.

important.title: The root User
important.para: The user &rootuser; has all the permissions needed to make changes to the system. To carry out such tasks, the &rootuser; password is required. You cannot carry out any administrative tasks without this password.

sect2.title: Registration Code or SMT Server URL
sect2.para: To get technical support and product updates, you need to register and activate your product with the &scc;. Registering &productname; now grants you immediate access to the update repository. This enables you to install the system with the latest updates and patches available.

note.title: Network Configuration
note.para: After booting into the installation, the installation routine is set up. During this setup, an attempt to configure all network interfaces with DHCP is made. In case DHCP is not available or if you want to modify the network configuration, click Network Configuration in the upper right corner of the &scc; Registration screen. The &yast; module Network Settings opens. See for details.

sect2.para: To register your system, provide the E-mail address associated with the &suse; account you or your organization uses to manage subscriptions. In case you do not have a SUSE account yet, go to the &scc; home page () to create one.
Enter the Registration Code you received with your copy of &productname;.

Proceed with Next to start the registration process. If one or more local registration servers are available on your network, you can choose one of them from a list—by default &productname; is registered at the &scc;. If your local registration server was not discovered automatically, choose Cancel, select Register System via local SMT Server and enter the URL of the server. Restart the registration by choosing Next again.
Enter the Registration Code or SMT Server URL. SMT Server URLs must use the https or http protocol; other schemes are not supported.

sect2.title: System Role
sect2.para: Select the System Role for your system.

listitem.para: The &admin_node; providing the administration dashboard for the cluster.
A cluster node running containers or the container orchestration framework.
A plain node that can be used for testing and debugging purposes in your cluster, but it is not usually needed.

sect2.title: NTP Servers
sect2.para: Enter host names or IP addresses of one or more NTP Servers for the node, separated by white spaces or colons. While a single server is sufficient, nodes should use at least three for optimal precision and reliability.
For more information about NTP, refer to

sect2.title: Partitioning
sect2.para: Review the partition setup proposed by the system and change it if necessary. You have the following options:

listitem.para: Select a disk to which install &productname; to with the recommended partitioning scheme.

Opens the Expert Partitioner described in
.

warning.title: For Experts only
warning.para: As the name suggests, the Expert Partitioner is for experts only. Custom partitioning schemes that do not meet the requirements of &productname; are not supported.

listitem.para: For snapshots, partitions must have a capacity of at least 11 GB.
Depending on the number and size of your containers, you will need sufficient space under the /var mount point.

sect2.para: To accept the proposed setup without any changes, choose Next to proceed.

sect2.title: Booting
sect2.para:
This section shows the boot loader configuration. Changing the defaults is only recommended if really needed. Refer to
for details.

sect2.title: Network Configuration
sect2.para: If the network could not be configured automatically while starting the installation system, you have to manually configure the Network Settings. Please make sure at least one network interface is connected to the Internet in order to register your product.
By default, the installer requests a host name from the DHCP server. If you set a custom name in the Hostname/DNS tab, make sure the it is unique.

For more information on configuring network connections, refer to
.

important.title: Reliable Networking
important.para: Please make sure all nodes are on the same network and can communicate without interruptions. If you are using host names to specify nodes, please make sure you have reliable DNS resolution at all times, especially in combination with DHCP.

sect2.title: &kdump;
sect2.para:
Kdump saves the memory image (core dump) to the file system in case the kernel crashes. This enables you to find the cause of the crash by debugging the dump file. See
for more information.

warning.title: Kdump with large amounts of RAM
warning.para: If you have a system with large amounts of RAM or a small hard drive, core dumps may not be able to fit on the disk. If the installer warns you about this, there are two options:

listitem.para: Enter the Expert Partitioner and increase the size of the root partition so that it can accommodate the size of the core dump. In this case, you will need to decrease the size of the data partition accordingly. Remember to keep all other parameters of the partitioning (e.g. the root file system, mount point of data partition) when doing these changes.
Disable kdump completely.

sect2.title: System Information
sect2.para:
View detailed hardware information by clicking System Information. In this screen you can also change Kernel Settings. See
for more information.

sect2.title: Installing the Controller Node
sect2.para: Use these instructions if there is no existing Linux system on your machine, or if you want to replace an existing Linux system.

step.para: Insert the &productname; DVD into the drive, then reboot the computer to start the installation program. On machines with a traditional BIOS you will see the graphical boot screen shown below. On machines equipped with UEFI, a slightly different boot screen is used. Secure boot on UEFI machines is supported.

Use F2 to change the language for the installer. A corresponding keyboard layout is chosen automatically. See
for more information about changing boot options.

figure.title: The Boot Screen on Machines with a Traditional BIOS

step.para: Select Installation on the boot screen, then press . This boots the system and loads the &productname; installer.
Configure the following mandatory settings on the Installation Overview screen.
Optionally, you can customize the following settings. If you do not make any changes, defaults are used. A brief summary of the settings is displayed below the respective settings option.
Proceed with Next.

tip.title: Installing Product Patches at Installation Time
tip.para: If &productname; has been successfully registered at the &scc;, you are asked whether to install the latest available online updates during the installation. If choosing Yes, the system will be installed with the most current packages without having to apply the updates after installation. Activating this option is recommended.

step.para: After you have finalized the system configuration on the Installation Overview screen, click Install. Up to this point no changes have been made to your system. After you click Install a second time, the installation process starts.
During the installation, the progress is shown in detail on the Details tab.
After the installation routine has finished, the computer is rebooted into the installed system.

sect2.title: Initial Cluster Configuration
sect2.para: In order to finalize the configuration of the &admin_node;, a few additional steps are required.

step.para:
After the &admin_node; has finished booting and you see the login prompt, point a web browser to https://caasp-admin.&exampledomain;
, where caasp-admin.&exampledomain; is the host name or IP address of the &admin_node;. The IP address is shown above the login prompt.

To create an Administrator account, click Create an account and provide an e-mail address and a password. Confirm the password and click Create Admin. You will be logged into the dashboard automatically.
Fill in the values for Dashboard Location and External Kubernetes API server FQDN. If necessary, configure the Proxy Settings.

listitem.para: Host name or IP of the node running this web interface.
Fully qualified domain name (FQDN) used to reach the cluster from the outside. In a simple, single master deployment this will be the FQDN of the node you are about to select as master.

If enabled, you can set proxy servers for HTTP and HTTPS. You may also configure exceptions and choose whether to apply the settings only to the container engine or to all processes running on the cluster nodes.

step.para: Click Next to proceed and install some cluster nodes as described in .

sect2.title: Installing Cluster Nodes
sect2.para: Cluster nodes can be installed manually or with &ay;. Manual installation is only feasible for a small number of workers. For larger numbers, &ay; is recommended.

You can directly use the initrd and linux files from your install media, or install the package tftpboot-installation-CAASP-1.0 on the TFTP server. The package provides the required initrd and linux files in the /srv/tftpboot/ directory. You need to modify the paths used in the &sle; 12 Deployment Guide to correctly point to the files provided by the package.
Before you can set up a cluster node, you have to install and bootstrap an &admin_node; to run the administration dashboard. Refer to for information on how to install the controller node.

step.para: Follow the steps as described in
In step 3, select Cluster Node as System Role and enter the host name or IP address of the Administration Node.

important.title: Reliable Networking
important.para: Please make sure all nodes are on the same network and can communicate without interruptions. If you are using host names to specify nodes, please make sure you have reliable DNS resolution at all times, especially in combination with DHCP.

step.para: After you have finalized the system configuration on the Installation Overview screen, click Install. Up to this point no changes have been made to your system. After you click Install a second time, the installation process starts.
After a reboot, the worker should show up in the dashboard and can be added to your cluster.

sect3.title: Installation with &ay;
sect3.para: Please make sure you have finished the initial configuration described in before installing cluster nodes with &ay;.

step.para: Insert the &productname; DVD into the drive, then reboot the computer to start the installation program.
Select Installation on the boot screen. Enter the necessary Boot Options for &ay; and networking, namely:

listitem.para: Path to the &ay; file. For more information, refer to
Network configuration. If you are using dhcp, you can simply enter dhcp. For manual configurations, refer to .
The host name for the node, if not provided by DHCP. If you manually specify a host name, make sure it is unique.

step.para: Press . This boots the system and loads the &productname; installer.
The rest of the installation will run fully automated. After a reboot, the worker should show up in the dashboard and can be added to your cluster.

sect2.title: Bootstrapping the Cluster
sect2.para: To complete the installation of your &productname; cluster, it is necessary to bootstrap at least three additional nodes; those will be the Kubernetes Master and Workers.

step.para:
Point a web browser to https://caasp-admin.&exampledomain;
to open the dashboard, where caasp-admin.&exampledomain; is the host name or IP address of the &admin_node;.
The dashboard lists all cluster nodes registered at the &admin_node;. Newly installed nodes are be listed as Pending Nodes. You can accept individual nodes or all by clicking Accept All Nodes.

Use the check box in the first column to select the nodes you want to add to your cluster. In the last column, select the one that should become Kubernetes Master. All other nodes will be set to the Worker role once you click Bootstrap cluster.
Please wait while the cluster is bootstrapped. Once finished, the status indicator icon of the nodes changes accordingly and you can download the kubectl configuration file.
